moves.1. d4: Game and comments by Italians IM Giorgio Porreca and Adriano Chicco-"Il Libro Completo Degli Scacchi" 8a ed. chapter XXIX: fianchetto bishop
moves.1... d5 2. c4 e5 3. dxe5 d4 4. Nf3 Nc6 5: Here Black looks good, instead his position is almost lost! The clash between appearance and the rising in a few moves reality makes White combo very nice.
moves.15. b4: It looks like a common pawn sac--it is instead the beginning of the end.
moves.15... axb4: Black is forced to take, because if 15... Ba7 16.c5 and White's advantage became clear.
moves.16. axb4 Nxb4: If 16... Bxb4 the d4 pawn is lost
moves.17. Qb3 Nc6: White was threatening at least 18.Ra8+ (or 18.h3!) with revenge on d4 pawn.
moves.18. Qb5 Bb6 19. Bxd4: 19.Bxd4!! This sac depends by previous one and allows the following, on move 21
moves.19... Bxd4 20. Nxd4 Rxd4 21. Qxb7+: 21.Qxb7+!! This sac is wonderfully possible, thanks to the strategic placement of Bg2.
moves.21... Kxb7 22. Rfb1+ Kc8 23. Bxc6 Qa3: To escape from mating net, in fact 23... Kd8; 24.Rb8+ Bc8 and 25.Rxc8+
moves.24. Rb8+: 24.Rb8+!! White finds the most elegant way to end this genial match, little known but that fully deserve to be considered a chess masterpiece.
